[[File:IMP Accomplishment Table-01.tif|thumb|This example of an IMP shows a table of events, accomplishments, and criteria—without a listing of the IMP narratives. The intent is to illustrate the hierarchical structure and relationship of events, accomplishments, criteria, and tasks.]]
In the [[United States Department of Defense]], the '''Integrated Master Plan''' ('''IMP)''' and the Integrated Master Schedule (IMS) are important [[program management]] tools that provide significant assistance in the planning and scheduling of work efforts in large and complex materiel acquisitions.<ref>{{cite web | title=''AFMC Pamphlet 63-5, Integrated Master Plan and Schedule Guide'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/USAF/USAF-AFMC/download.php?spec=AFMC_PAM_63-5.004210.pdf | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Air Force]] | date=11 Nov 2004 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> The IMP is an event-driven plan that documents the significant accomplishments necessary to complete the work and ties each accomplishment to a key program event.<ref>{{cite web | title=''Integrated Master Plan (IMP) / Integrated Master Schedule (IMS)'' | url=https://acc.dau.mil/CommunityBrowser.aspx?id=24654 | publisher=[[Defense Acquisition University]] | accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> The IMP is expanded to a time-based IMS to produce a networked and multi-layered schedule showing all detailed tasks required to accomplish the work effort contained in the IMP. The IMS flows directly from the IMP and supplements it with additional levels of detail——both then form the foundations to implement an [[Earned Value Management| Earned Value Management System]].
* The IMP is a bilateral agreement between the Government and a contractor on what defines the “event-driven” program. The IMP documents the key events, accomplishments, and the evaluation "criteria" in the development, production and/or modification of a military system; moreover, the IMS provides sequential events and key decision points (generally meetings) to assess program progress. Usually the IMP is a contractual document. * Supporting the IMP is the IMS that is made up of "tasks" depicting the work effort needed to complete the "criteria".<ref>{{cite web | title=''Scheduling Guide for Program Managers'' | url=http://www.dau.mil/publications/publicationsDocs/schedulinguide.pdf | format=PDF | publisher= Defense Systems Management College Press, Fort Belvoir, VA | date=October 2001 |accessdate=19 Jan 2016}}</ref> It is a detailed time-driven plan for program execution that helps to ensure on-time delivery dates are achieved, and that tracking and status tool are used during program execution. These tools must show progress, interrelationships and dependencies.
In civic planning or [[urban planning]], ''Integrated Master Plan'' is used at the levels of city <ref>{{cite web | title=''City of Riverside, Wastewater Integrated Master Plan'' | url=http://www.riversideca.gov/pworks/masterplan-wastewater.asp}}</ref> development,<ref>{{cite web | title=''Integrated Master Plan for Lahore 2021'' | url=http://www.urbanunit.gov.pk/pubpublic/pubcomp/70.pdf}}</ref> county,<ref>{{cite web | title=''Santa Clara County Parks, Draft Integrated Master Plan'' | url=http://sccgov.iqm2.com/Citizens/FileOpen.aspx?Type=4&ID=101252}}</ref> and state or province to refer to a document integrating diverse aspects of a [[public works]] project.
== Purpose and Objectives == The primary purpose of the IMP—and the supporting detailed schedules of the IMS—is their use by the U.S. Government and Contractor acquisition team as the day-to-day tools for the planning, executing, and tracking program technical, schedule, and cost status, including risk mitigation efforts.<ref>{{cite web | title=''Integrated Master Plan and Integrated Master Schedule Preparation and Use Guide'' | url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/se/docs/IMP_IMS_Guide_v9.pdf | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |work=Ver. 0.9 |date=31 Oct 2005 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> The IMP provides a better structure than either the [[Work breakdown structure|Work Breakdown Structure]] (WBS) or [[Organizational chart|Organizational Breakdown Structure]] (OBS) for measuring actual integrated master schedule (IMS) progress.<ref>{{cite web |author=Bachman, David C.| title=''Better Schedule Performance Assessments Derived From Integrated Master Plan-Referenced Schedule Metrics'' | url=http://www.dau.mil/pubscats/PubsCats/AR%20Journal/arj60/Bachman_ARJ60.pdf | format=PDF | publisher=[[Defense Acquisition University]] |date=October 2011 |work=Defense Acquisition Research Journal (ARJ) |pages=406–427 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref>
The primary objective of the IMP is a single plan that establishes the program or project fundamentals. It provides a hierarchical, event-based plan that contains: Events; Significant accomplishments; Entry and exit criteria; however it does not include any dates or durations. Using the IMP provides sufficient definition for explain program process and completion tracking, as well as providing effective communication of the program/project content and the "''What and How''" of the program.
== Rationale == The IMP is a collection of [[Milestone (project management)|milestones]] (called "events") that form the process architecture of the program. This means the sequence of events must always result in a deliverable product or service. While delivering products or services is relatively straight forward in some instances (i.e., list the tasks to be done, arrange them in the proper sequence, and execute to this “plan”), in other cases, problems often arise: (i) the description of "complete" is often missing for intermediate activities; (ii) program partners, integration activities, and subcontractors all have unknown or possibly unknowable impacts on the program; and (iii) as products or services are delivered the maturity of the program changes (e.g., quality and functionality expectations, as well as other attributes)——this maturity provided by defining "complete" serves as an insurance policy against future problems encountered later in the program.
Often, it's easier to define the IMP by stating what it is not. The IMP is NOT BASED on calendar dates, and therefore it is not schedule oriented; each event is completed when its supporting accomplishments are completed, and this completion is evidenced by the satisfaction of the criteria supporting each of the accomplishments. Furthermore, many of the IMP events are fixed by customer-defined milestones (e.g., Preliminary or Critical Design Review, Production Deliver, etc.) while intermediate events are defined by the Supplier (e.g., integration and test, software build releases, Test Readiness Review, etc.).
The critical IMP attribute is its focus on events, when compared to effort or task focused planning. The event focus asks and answers the question ''what does done look like?'' rather than what work has been done. Certainly work must be done to complete a task, but a focus solely on the work hides the more important metric of ''are we meeting our commitments?'' While meeting commitments is critical, it's important to first define the criteria used for judging if the commitments are being met. This is where Significant Accomplishments (SA) and their Accomplishment Criteria (AC) become important. It is important to meet commitments, but recognizing when the commitment has been met is even more important.
== Attributes and Characteristics ==
The IMP provides Program Traceability by expanding and complying with the program's Statement of Objectives (SOO), Technical Performance Requirements (TPRs), the Contract [[Work Breakdown Structure]] (CWBS), and the Contract [[Statement of work|Statement of Work]] (CSOW)—all of which are based on the Customer's WBS to form the basis of the IMS and all cost reporting. The IMP implements a measurable and trackable program structure to accomplish integrated product development, integrate the functional program activities, and incorporates functional, lower-level and subcontractor IMPs. The IMP provides a framework for independent evaluation of Program Maturity by allowing insight into the overall effort with a level-of-detail that is consistent with levied risk and complexity metrics. It uses the methodology of decomposing events into a logical series of accomplishments having measurable criteria to demonstrate the completion and/or quality of accomplishments.
== Requirements Flowdown ==
A Government customer tasks a Supplier to prepare and implement an IMP that linked with the IMS and integrated with the EVMS. The IMP list the contract requirements documents (e.g., Systems Requirements Document and Technical Requirements Document (i.e., the system specification or similar document)) as well as the IMP events corresponding to development and/or production activities required by the contract. The IMP should include significant accomplishments encompassing all steps necessary to satisfy all contract objectives and requirements, manage all significant risks, and facilitate Government insight for each event. Significant accomplishments shall be networked to show their logical relationships and that they flow logically from one to another. The IMP, IMS, and EVMS products will usually include the prime contractor, subcontractor, and major vendor activities and products.<ref>{{cite web | title=''SMC-S-019, Rev. A'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/USAF/USAF-SMC/download.php?spec=SMC-S-019A_11AUG2008.021545.PDF | format=PDF | publisher=[[Space and Missile Systems Center]], Air Force Space Command, El Segundo, CA | date=11 Aug 2008 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref>
== Evaluation of an IMS ==
When evaluating a proposed IMS, the user should focus on realistic task durations, predecessor/successor relationships, and identification of [[critical path method|critical path]] tasks with viable risk mitigation and contingency plans. An IMS summarized at too high a level may result in obscuring critical execution elements, and contributing to failure of the EVMS to report progress. A high-level IMS may fail to show related [[risk management]] approaches being used, which can result in long duration tasks and artificial linkages masking the true critical path. In general, the IMP is a top-down planning tool and the IMS as the bottom-up execution tool. It should be noted, however, the IMS is a scheduling tool for management control of program progression, not for cost collection purposes.<ref>{{cite web | title=''Systems Engineering Guide: Integrated Master Schedule (IMS)/Integrated Master Plan (IMP) Application'' | url=http://www.mitre.org/work/systems_engineering/guide/acquisition_systems_engineering/acquisition_program_planning/integrated_master_schedule_master_plan_application.html | publisher=Mitre Corporation] | date= |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref>
An IMS would seek general consistency and a standardized approach to project planning, scheduling and analysis. It may use guides such as the PASEG Generally Accepted Schedule Principles (GASP) as guidance to improve execution and enable EVMS.<ref>{{cite web | title = Planning & Scheduling Excellence Guide (PASEG), Version 3.0 | url = https://www.humphreys-assoc.com/evms/planning-scheduling-excellence-guide-paseg-version-ta-a-175-t-1_25_32.html | publisher = NDIA | accessdate = 17 Nov 2017}}</ref>
== Relationship to other Documents ==
The IMP/IMS are related to the product-based ''' [[Work Breakdown Structure]] (WBS)''' as defined in MIL-STD-881, by giving a second type of view on the effort, for different audiences or to provide a combination which gives better overall understanding.<ref>{{cite web | title=''Department of Defense Standard: Work Breakdown Structures (WBS) for Defense Material Items (Superseding MIL-HDBK-881A)'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/MIL-STD/MIL-STD-0800-0899/download.php?spec=MIL-STD-881C.037590.pdf/ | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=3 Oct 2011 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> Linkage between the IMP/IMS and WBS is done by referencing the WBS numbering whenever the PE (Program Event), SA (Significant Accomplishment), or AC (Accomplishment Criteria) involves a deliverable product.
== Reporting Formats ==
The IMP is often called out as a contract data deliverable on [[United States Department of Defense]] materiel acquisitions, as well as other U.S. Government procurements. Formats for these deliverables are covered in [[Data Item Descriptions]] (DIDs) that define the data content, format, and data usages. Recently, the DoD cancelled the DID (DI-MISC-81183A) that jointly addressed both the IMP and the IMS.<ref>{{cite web | title=''DI-MISC-81183A, Data Item Description: Integrated Master Schedule (IMS)'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/DATA-ITEM-DESC-DIDs/DI-MISC/DI-MISC-81183A_11978/ | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=9 Feb 1996 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> The replacement documents include DI-MGMT-81650 (Integrated Master Schedule), DI-MGMT-81334A (Contract Work Breakdown Structure) and DI-MGMT-81466 (Contract Performance Report).<ref>{{cite web | title=''DI-MGMT-81650, Data Item Description: Integrated Master Schedule (IMS)'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/DATA-ITEM-DESC-DIDs/DI-MGMT/DI-MGMT-81650_12009/ | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=30 Mar 2005 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=''DI-MISC-81334D, Data Item Description: Contract Work Breakdown Structure'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/DATA-ITEM-DESC-DIDs/DI-MGMT/download.php?spec=DI-MGMT-81334D.034122.pdf/ | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=''DI-MISC-81466A, Data Item Description: Cost Performance Report (CPR)'' | url=http://www.everyspec.com/DATA-ITEM-DESC-DIDs/DI-MGMT/DI-MGMT-81466A_16102/ | format=PDF | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | date=30 Mar 2005 |accessdate=7 Aug 2012}}</ref> In addition DFARS 252.242–7001 and 252.242–7002 provide guidance for integrating IMP/IMS with [[Earned Value Management]].
== References ==

revision.text:
{{Redirect|ISBER|the Institute of Social, Behavioral and Economic Research|University of California, Santa Barbara#Institutes and Programs}} {{multiple issues| {{advert|date=May 2018}} {{notability|Companies|date=May 2018}} {{third-party|date=May 2018}} }} {{copypaste|url=http://www.isber.org/?page=BPR|date=May 2018}} The '''International Society for Biological and Environmental Repositories (ISBER)'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isber.org |title=ISBER |publisher=ISBER |date=2014-01-23 |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref> is the largest international forum that addresses the technical, legal, ethical, and managerial issues relevant to [[Biorepository|repositories]] of biological and environmental specimens. ISBER is a professional society of individuals and organizations who share an interest in promoting consistent, high quality standards, ethical principles and innovation in biospecimen banking by uniting the global [[biobanks|biobanking]] community. ISBER invites all sub-components of government, academia, the private sector, and manufacturers to become active participants of the society.
== Mission == ISBER is a global organization which creates opportunities for sharing ideas and innovations in biobanking and harmonizes approaches to evolving challenges for biological and environmental repositories.
ISBER fosters collaboration, creates education and training opportunities, provides an international showcase for state-of-the-art policies, processes, and research findings, and innovative technologies, products, and services. Together, these activities promote best practices that cut across the broad range of repositories that ISBER serves.<ref name="isber.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.isber.org/?page=About |title=About |publisher=ISBER |date=2014-01-23 |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref>
== Vision == ISBER will be the leading global forum for promoting harmonized high quality standards, ethical principles, and innovation in the science and management of biorepositories.<ref name="isber.org"/>
==Membership== Membership includes organizations and individuals from over 30 countries involved in long-term preservation and storage of animal, environmental, human, microorganism culture, museum, and plant/seed collections.
==Members== ISBER has members from all around the world. Here are some of them:

The complete list is available over official website.
==Meetings== ISBER holds one international meeting each year. Lectures, workshops, poster presentations, and working group discussions focus on technical issues and challenges such as quality assurance and control, regulations, human subject privacy and confidentiality issues, and provide information about sources of equipment and expertise.
=== ISBER Annual Meeting Locations === * May 20–24, 2014 - Orlando, FL, USA * 2013 - Sydney, NSW, Australia * 2012 - Vancouver, BC, Canada * 2011 - Arlington, VA, USA * 2010 - Rotterdam, SH, Netherlands * 2009 - Portland, OR, USA * 2008 - Bethesda, MD, USA * 2007 - Singapore * 2006 - Bethesda, MD, USA * 2005 - Bellevue, WA, USA * 2004 - New York, NY, USA
==Best Practices== The availability of high quality biological and environmental specimens for research purposes requires the development of standardized methods for collection, long-term storage, retrieval and distribution of specimens that will enable their future use. Sharing successful strategies for accomplishing this goal is one of the driving forces for the International Society for Biological and Environmental Repositories (ISBER).
ISBER's Best Practices for Repositories (Best Practices) reflects the collective experience of its members and has received broad input from other repository professionals. Throughout this document effective practices are presented for the management of specimen collections and repositories. The term "Best Practice" is used in cases where a level of operation is indicated that is above the basic recommended practice or, more specifically, designates the most effective practice. It is understood that repositories in certain locations or with particular financial constraints may not be able to adhere to each of the items designated as "Best Practices". Repositories fitting into either of these categories will need to decide how they might best adhere to these recommendations within their particular circumstances. While adherence to ISBER Best Practices is strictly on a voluntary basis, it is important to note that some aspects of specimen management are governed by national/federal, regional and local regulations. The reader should refer directly to regulations for their national/federal, regional and local requirements, as appropriate.
The ISBER Best Practices are periodically reviewed and revised to reflect advances in research and technology. The third edition of the Best Practices builds on the foundation established in the first and second editions which were published in 2005 and 2008, respectively.
=== Current Best Practices === ''ISBER Best Practices For Repositories: Collection, Storage, Retrieval and Distribution of Biological Materials for Research'' provides repository professionals with standardized guidelines for the management of [[biobank specimen]]<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Vaught | first1 = J. B. | last2 = Caboux | first2 = E. | last3 = Hainaut | first3 = P. | doi = 10.1158/1055-9965.EPI-10-0058 | title = International Efforts to Develop Biospecimen Best Practices | journal = Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention | volume = 19 | issue = 4 | pages = 912–5 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20233852 | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="foundation">{{Cite journal | last1 = Hewitt | first1 = R. E. | title = Biobanking: The foundation of personalized medicine | journal = Current Opinion in Oncology | volume = 23 | issue = 1 | pages = 112–119 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21076300 | doi = 10.1097/CCO.0b013e32834161b8 }}</ref><ref name="BPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.isber.org/?page=BPR |title=Best Practices For Repositories |publisher=ISBER |date=2014-01-23 |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref> collections and repositories. The most current version of the ISBER Best Practices was published in ''[[Biopreservation and Biobanking]]'' (BIO), April 2012 issue.<ref name="BPR"/>
=== Self-Assessment Tool (SAT) === ISBER has created this Self-Assessment Tool(SAT) to assist repository operators in determining how well their repository follows the ISBER Best Practices for Repositories.The assessment is confidential and aimed at helping specimen collection centers strengthen their practices through the identification of areas in need of improvement.
ISBER provides a yearly anonymized SAT result summary, found on the ISBER website here [http://www.isber.org/?page=SATsummary].
==== SAT Information ==== The tool contains 158 questions which may be answered in a single or multiple sessions. Each page of the survey corresponds to a section of the ISBER Best Practices. Results from pilot tests indicated that the SAT takes a little over an hour to complete if all required information is available at the time of completing the survey. The tool is free to ISBER members, and non-members may participate for a fee.
After completion of the SAT, a personalized e-mail is sent to the participant which includes a "risk-balanced assessment score" and notification of top deviation areas to help the participant evaluate how their current practices conform to the ISBER Best Practices. The score is based on possible risk to the specimens, frequency of implementation of each practice, and the ease with which deviations can be detected.
==Biorepository Proficiency Testing Program== Developed in collaboration with the Integrated Biobank of Luxembourg (IBBL), the Biorepository Proficiency Testing Program is designed to allow biorepositories to assess the accuracy of their quality control assays and characterization of biospecimens. Participants can compare their results with those obtained in other laboratories and can identify testing issues that may be related to individual staff performance or calibration of instrumentation used in biospecimen quality control. The program provides guidance to biorepositories so they can take appropriate remedial action to be in compliance with ISO/IEC 17043:2010, providing a necessary External Quality Assessment tool for biorepositories who wish to seek accreditation (ISO 17025, CLIA or equivalent).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isber.org/?page=whypt |title=Why Proficiency Testing? |publisher=ISBER |date= |accessdate=2014-07-18}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.isber.org/}}
[[Category:Biorepositories]] [[Category:Biobank organizations]] [[Category:Environmental organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Organizations based in Vancouver]]

The '''International Society for Biosemiotic Studies''' (ISBS) is an academic society for the researchers in [[semiotic biology]]. The Society was established in 2005.<ref>Favareau, Don 2005. Founding a world biosemiotics institution: The International Society for Biosemiotic Studies. ''[[Sign Systems Studies]]'' 33(2): 481-485.</ref> Its official journal is [[Biosemiotics (journal)|Biosemiotics]], published by [[Springer Science|Springer]] and launched in 2008.
The purpose of the ISBS is to constitute an organizational framework for the collaboration among scholars dedicated to biosemiotic studies, including the [[interdisciplinary]] research of [[sign process]]es in [[living system]]s, organic codes, and [[biocommunication (science)|biocommunication]]. The ISBS attempts to develop the [[qualitative research]] methods in biology. Among the central focuses is also [[theoretical semiotics]] as a basis for [[theoretical biology]].
The ISBS assures the organization of regular meetings on research into the semiotics of nature, as well as promotes publication of scholarly work on the semiotics of life processes. The ISBS organizes the annual international conferences (''Gatherings in Biosemiotics'') that were started by Copenhagen and Tartu biosemioticians and have taken place regularly already since 2001.<ref>[[Claus Emmeche|Emmeche, Claus]] 2001. The emergence of signs of living feeling: Reverberations from the first Gatherings in Biosemiotics. ''Sign Systems Studies'' 29(1): 369–376.</ref><ref>Rattasepp, Silver; Bennett, Tyler (eds.) 2012. ''Gatherings in Biosemiotics''. (Tartu Semiotics Library 11.) Tartu: University of Tartu Press.</ref>
The first President of the ISBS was [[Jesper Hoffmeyer]] (Copenhagen University), the second President (since 2015) is [[Kalevi Kull]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.biosemiotics.org/ Homepage of the International Society for Biosemiotic Studies] *[https://www.springer.com/life+sci/journal/12304 ''Biosemiotics'', the official journal of the Society]
[[Category:International scientific organizations]] [[Category:Biology organizations]] [[Category:Semiotics organizations]]

revision.text:
{{About||actual islands that are part of this peninsula|List of coastal islands of the Californias}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2015}} [[File:California island Vinckeboons5.jpg|380px|right|thumbnail|Map of California, circa 1650; restored. The [[compass rose]] in the center of the map marks the approximate location of the modern [[US-Mexico border]], south of [[San Diego]].]] [[File:Insel Kalifornien 1650.jpg|right|thumbnail|The "Island of California" is shown on a 1650 map by Nicolas Sanson]] [[File:Baja peninsula (mexico) 250m.jpg|thumb|right|upright|237px||A satellite view of Baja California Peninsula and the Gulf of California]] The '''Island of California''' refers to a long-held Spanish misconception, dating from the 16th century, that the [[Baja California Peninsula]] was not part of mainland [[History of the west coast of North America|North America]] but rather a large island (spelled on early maps as Cali Fornia) separated from the continent by a strait now known as the [[Gulf of California]]. One of the most famous [[cartography|cartographic]] errors in history, it was propagated on many maps during the 17th and 18th centuries, despite contradictory evidence from various explorers. The legend was initially infused with the idea that California was a terrestrial paradise, like the [[Garden of Eden]] or [[Atlantis]]. == History == The first known mention of the legend of the "Island of California" was in the 1510 romance novel ''[[Las sergas de Esplandián]]'' by [[Garci Rodríguez de Montalvo]]—the sequel to Montalvo's more famous tales of [[Amadis de Gaula]], father of Esplandian. He described the island in this passage:
Know, that on the right hand of the Indies there is an island called California very close to the side of the Terrestrial Paradise; and it is peopled by black women, without any man among them, for they live in the manner of [[Amazons]].{{cite book |last= Rodríguez de Montalvo |first= Garci |authorlink= Garci Rodríguez de Montalvo |year= 1526 |origyear= 1496 |title= Las sergas de Esplandián |trans-title=The Adventures of Esplandián |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZWcBYnKWya0C&pg=PA187&q=%22mucho%22&f=false#v=onepage |language= Spanish |quote= Sabed que ala diestra mano de las Indias ouo una Isla llamada California mucho llegada ala parte del paraiso terrenal la qual sue poblada de mugeres negras sin que algun uaro entre ellas ouiesse: que casi como las amazonas ...}} (The first mention of "California" occurs on the unnumbered page after page CVIII, in the right column.)
It is probable that this description prompted early explorers to misidentify the [[Baja California Peninsula]] as the island in these legends. In 1533, [[Fortún Ximénez]], a mutineer on an exploring expedition sent by [[Hernán Cortés]], discovered the southern portion of Baja California, around present-day [[La Paz, Baja California Sur|La Paz]]. He was killed by natives but his men returned to [[New Spain]] and gave report of their find. In 1535 Cortés arrived in the bay there and named the area Santa Cruz; he attempted to start a colony but abandoned his efforts after several years due to logistical problems. Cortés' limited information on southern Baja California apparently led to the naming of the region after the legendary California and to an initial but short-lived assumption that it was a large island.{{cite book|last= Polk |first= Dora Beale |title= The Island of California: A History of the Myth |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=iKNqcBIbhqMC&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=%22When+the+explorers+came+across+Baja,+what+they+thought+they+found+was+an+island.%22&source=bl&ots=7gDfq2SBuI&sig=wp2shpmQMmFOlVo9Cu_HoALjcQI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uX-9U7mSE8GfyATM1YHgDQ&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22When%20the%20explorers%20came%20across%20Baja%2C%20what%20they%20thought%20they%20found%20was%20an%20island.%22&f=false |publisher= [[University of Nebraska Press]] |date= 1995-10-01 |page= 105 |series= Spain in the West |isbn= 978-0-8032-8741-9 |quote= Cortés Believes Baja California to be an Island}}{{cite book|last= Portillo |first= Álvaro del |authorlink= Álvaro del Portillo |title= Descubrimientos y exploraciones en las costas de California, 1532–1650 |trans-title=Discoveries and explorations along the coast of California, 1532–1650 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=nn3wEhP-8SYC&pg=PA140&lpg=PA140&dq=%22Sin+embargo,+es+indudable+que+Cort%C3%A9s,+el+envidiado,+habl%C3%B3+de+una+isla%22&source=bl&ots=K8XztpLXn1&sig=uSA22836B3mmYQKVHv2h_J7bg6E&hl=en&sa=X&ei=b5-9U9LCMY6byASF7oGYAQ&ved=0CBQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Sin%20embargo%2C%20es%20indudable%20que%20Cort%C3%A9s%2C%20el%20envidiado%2C%20habl%C3%B3%20de%20una%20isla%22&f=false |year= 1982 |origyear= 1944 |edition= 2nd |language= Spanish |publisher= Ediciones Rialp |location= [[Madrid]] |page= 140 |isbn= 9788432121890 |quote= Sin embargo, es indudable que Cortés, el envidiado, habló de una isla de riqueza fantástica." ["However, it is clear that Cortés, with envy, spoke of a fantastic island of wealth."]}} (The 1944 edition was the author's doctoral thesis.) In 1539, Cortés sent the navigator [[Francisco de Ulloa]] northward along the Gulf and Pacific coasts of Baja California. Ulloa reached the mouth of the [[Colorado River]] at the head of the Gulf, which seemed to prove that the region was a peninsula rather than an island.{{cite web|last= Wood |first= Mark |title= The Island of California |url= http://magazine.pomona.edu/2014/spring/the-island-of-california/ |date= 2014-03-11 | website= Pomona College Magazine |publisher= [[Pomona College]] |accessdate= 2014-07-10}} An expedition under [[Hernando de Alarcón]] ascended the lower Colorado River and confirmed Ulloa's finding. Maps published subsequently in Europe during the 16th century, including those by [[Gerardus Mercator]] and [[Abraham Ortelius]], correctly showed Baja California as a peninsula. Despite this evidence, however, the depiction of California as an island revived in the early 17th century. One contributing factor may have been the second voyage of [[Juan de Fuca]] in 1592. De Fuca claimed to have explored the western coast of North America and to have found a large opening that possibly connected to the Atlantic Ocean — the legendary [[Northwest Passage]]. De Fuca's claim remains controversial because there is only one surviving written account of it found, his account as related to an Englishman, [[Michael Locke (merchant)|Michael Locke]]. Nonetheless, this account claims de Fuca found a large strait, with a large island at its mouth, at around 47° north [[latitude]]. The [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]] is in fact at around 48° N, as is the southern tip of the large island now called [[Vancouver Island]], while the northern reach of the Gulf of California terminates much farther south, at about 31° N. It is possible that explorers and mapmakers in the 17th century could have confused the two (if in fact they were aware of de Fuca's voyage), and in any case further exploration was inevitable. Indeed, the famed British explorer [[James Cook]] narrowly missed the Strait of Juan de Fuca in March 1778, almost 200 years later. Cook even named [[Cape Flattery]] (at the northwest tip of modern [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state) which is at the mouth of the strait, and instead stopped in [[Nootka Sound]] just off the west coast of Vancouver Island at about 49° N. His account states "we saw nothing like [the Strait of Juan de Fuca]; nor is there the least probability that ever any such thing existed."{{cite book |title= A Voyage to the Pacific Ocean: Undertaken by the Command of His Majesty, for Making Discoveries in the Northern Hemisphere, to Determine the Position and Extent of the West Side of North America, its Distance from Asia, and the Practicability of a Northern Passage to Europe, ...|last1= Cook |first1= James |authorlink1= James Cook |publisher= W. and A. Strahan |location= [[London]] |volume= 2 |page= 263 |accessdate= 2018-05-31 |year=1784 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YukbZOe3D30C&pg=PA263&dq=%22the+pretended+strait+of+Juan+de+Fuca.+We+saw+nothing+like+it;+nor+is+there+the+least+probability+that+ever+any+such+thing+existed%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBq7rf2bDbAhXMz1QKHcwVCyIQ6AEIPDAD#v=onepage&q=%22the%20pretended%20strait%20of%20Juan%20de%20Fuca.%20We%20saw%20nothing%20like%20it%3B%20nor%20is%20there%20the%20least%20probability%20that%20ever%20any%20such%20thing%20existed%22&f=false}} However, Cook describes some bad weather in his account around this time, and did continue on to map most of the outer Pacific coastline of North America from modern-day northern California to the [[Bering Strait]] in [[Alaska]] on the same voyage. A key role in changing ideas about California seems to have been played by an overland expedition led by the founding governor of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]], [[Juan de Oñate]]. The expedition descended the Colorado River in 1604 and 1605, and its participants believed that they saw the Gulf of California continuing off to the northwest (presumably behind in the Sierra Cucapá into the Laguna Macuata Basin). Reports from Oñate's expedition reached Antonio de la Ascención, a [[Carmelites|Carmelite]] friar who had participated in [[Sebastián Vizcaíno]]'s explorations of the west coast of California in 1602 and 1603. Ascención was a tireless propagandist in favor of Spanish settlement in California, and his later writings referred to the region as an island. As older maps confirm, Spanish authorities and local residents were well aware where the actual northern terminus of the Gulf of California lay, but by extending the coastline north past [[Cape Mendocino]] and eventually even into [[Puget Sound]], [[Francis Drake|Sir Francis Drake]]'s claim of [[Nova Albion]] for England (1579) could be invalidated by the priority of Cortes' claim (1533). The first known reappearance of the Island of California on a map dates to 1622 in a map by Michiel Colijn of Amsterdam. The image became the standard for many later maps throughout the 17th century and intermittently into the 18th century. Previous maps show the Gulf terminating in its correct location. On the stretch of the Gulf between its actual terminus and Juan de Fuca's strait was written ''Mare Vermexo'' ("Red Sea"{{citation needed|date = August 2017}}) on later maps drawn from Spanish sources. The [[Jesuit]] missionary and cartographer [[Eusebio Kino|Eusebio Francisco Kino]] revived the fact that Baja California was a peninsula. While studying in Europe, Kino had accepted the insularity of California, but when he reached Mexico he began to have doubts. He made a series of overland expeditions from northern [[Sonora]] to areas within or near the Colorado River's delta in 1698–1706, in part to provide a practical route between the Jesuits' missions in Sonoran and Baja California but also to resolve the geographical question. Kino satisfied himself that a land connection must exist, and the 18th century Jesuits generally followed his example. The first report of Kino's discovery and his map from 1701 showing California as a peninsula were sent to Europe by [[Marcus Antonius Kappus]], a [[Jesuit]] missionary from [[Kamna Gorica, Radovljica|Kamna Gorica]] ([[Duchy of Carniola]], now Slovenia). In a June 1701 letter, he wrote about that to his friend Philippus Alberth in Vienna and thus acted as an important intermediary in the dissemination of this knowledge. However, Juan Mateo Manje, a military companion on several of Kino's treks, expressed scepticism; European cartographers remained divided on the question. Jesuit missionary-explorers in Baja California who attempted to lay the issue finally to rest included Juan de Ugarte (1721), [[Ferdinand Konščak]] (1746), and [[Wenceslaus Linck]] (1766). The matter was settled beyond all dispute when the expeditions of [[Juan Bautista de Anza]] traveled between Sonora and the west coast of California in the period 1774–1776. == See also == * [[Etymology of California]] == Notes == {{reflist|30em}} == References == * Laylander, Don, 2004. "Geographies of Fact and Fantasy: Oñate on the Lower Colorado River, 1604–1605". ''Southern California Quarterly'' 86:309–324. * León-Portilla, Miguel. 1989. ''{{lang|es|Cartografía y crónicas de la antigua California}}''. Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Mexico City. * McLaughlin, Glen, with Nancy H. Mayo. ''The Mapping of California as an Island: An Illustrated Checklist''. Saratoga, CA: California Map Society, 1995 . * Tooley, R. V. 1964. ''California as an Island: A Geographical Misconception Illustrated by 100 Examples from 1625–1770''. [[Map Collectors' Circle]], London. == External links == * [https://exhibits.stanford.edu/california-as-an-island California as an Island in Maps] online exhibit of [[Glen McLaughlin]] collection [[Category:Spanish folklore]] [[Category:Symbols of California]] [[Category:Latin American folklore]] [[Category:Mythological islands|California]] [[Category:Phantom islands|California]] [[Category:Obsolete scientific theories]] [[Category:The Californias]] [[Category:History of the Gulf of California]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Dame Jane Francis | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = |office = Chancellor of the [[University of Leeds]] |term_start = 9 July 2018 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Melvyn Bragg]] |successor = | birth_name = Jane Elizabeth Francis | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1956|10|}} | birth_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = British | alma_mater = [[University of Southampton]] | website = [https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#about Jane Francis at British Antarctic Survey]}} | module = {{Infobox scientist | embed = yes | fields = [[Palaeoclimatology]] | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[British Antarctic Survey]] * [[University of Adelaide]] * [[University of Leeds]]}} | thesis_title = The fossil forests of the basal Purbeck formation (upper jurassic) of Dorset, Southern England | thesis_url = http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.345489 | thesis_year = 1982 | doctoral_advisor = <!--(or | doctoral_advisors = )--> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = }} | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Polar Medal]] <small>(2002)</small> * [[Dame Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] <small>(2017)</small> }}
'''Dame Jane Elizabeth Francis''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DCMG}} is the Director of the [[British Antarctic Survey]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#about|title=Jane Francis|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bas.ac.uk|publisher=British Antarctic Survey|access-date=7 June 2016}}</ref> She previously worked as Professor of [[Palaeoclimatology]] at the [[University of Leeds]] where she also was Dean of the Faculty of Environment.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Frakes | first1 = L. A. | last2 = Francis | first2 = J. E. | doi = 10.1038/333547a0 | title = A guide to Phanerozoic cold polar climates from high-latitude ice-rafting in the Cretaceous | journal = Nature | volume = 333 | issue = 6173 | page = 547 | year = 1988 | pmid = | pmc = | bibcode = 1988Natur.333..547F }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0195-6671(92)90001-7| title = Australian cretaceous terrestrial faunas and floras: Biostratigraphic and biogeographic implications| journal = Cretaceous Research| volume = 13| issue = 3| page = 207| year = 1992| last1 = Dettmann | first1 = M. E. | last2 = Molnar | first2 = R. E. | last3 = Douglas | first3 = J. G. | last4 = Burger | first4 = D.| last5 = Fielding | first5 = C.| last6 = Clifford | first6 = H. T. | last7 = Francis | first7 = J.| last8 = Jell | first8 = P.| last9 = Rich | first9 = T.| last10 = Wade | first10 = M.| last11 = Rich | first11 = P. V. | last12 = Pledge | first12 = N.| last13 = Kemp | first13 = A.| last14 = Rozefelds | first14 = A.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0031-0182(01)00452-7| title = Cretaceous and early Tertiary climates of Antarctica: Evidence from fossil wood| journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology| volume = 182| page = 47| year = 2002| last1 = Francis | first1 = J. E. | last2 = Poole | first2 = I. | bibcode = 2002PPP...182...47F}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0037-0738(00)00034-8| title = PC99: A new freeware for manipulating and graphically displaying palaeocurrent data| journal = Sedimentary Geology| volume = 133| page = 1| year = 2000| last1 = Woolfe | first1 = K. J. | last2 = Stewart | first2 = L. K. | last3 = Francis | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Arnot | first4 = M. J. | bibcode = 2000SedG..133....1W}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05nv1wd|title=Jane Francis interviewed by Jim Al-Khalili|publisher=BBC}}</ref> In 2002 she was the fourth woman to receive the [[Polar Medal]] for outstanding contribution to British polar research. She is currently the Chancellor of the [[University of Leeds]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.leeds.ac.uk/info/110000/executive_group|title=Senior lay officers and the executive|last=Solutions|first=Web|website=www.leeds.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref name="University of Leeds Faculty of Environment">{{cite web | url=http://www.see.leeds.ac.uk/see-research/igs/seddies/francis/cv.htm | title=University of Leeds | publisher=University of Leeds Faculty of Environment | date=2011 | accessdate=23 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023084416/http://www.see.leeds.ac.uk/see-research/igs/seddies/francis/cv.htm |archivedate=23 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Scopus|id=7201708378}}</ref>
==Education== Francis was educated at [[Simon Langton Girls' Grammar School]] in Canterbury, and received both her undergraduate degree in Geology and her PhD from the [[University of Southampton]].<ref name=phd>{{cite thesis|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Southampton|title=The fossil forests of the basal Purbeck formation (upper jurassic) of Dorset, Southern England.|first= Jane E.|last=Francis|date=1982|url=http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.345489|oclc=}}</ref>
==Career== Francis was a [[Natural Environment Research Council|NERC]] research student in geology/biology at [[Southampton University]] from 1979 until 1982.<ref name=":0" /> She continued on as a NERC Postdoctoral Research Fellow at [[Bedford College, London|Bedford College]], London, until 1984.<ref name=":0" /> She was appointed to a position as Palaeobotanist at the [[British Antarctic Survey|British Antarctic Survey (BAS)]], from 1984–1986.<ref name=":0" />
For five years Francis was a [[Postdoctoral research|Postdoctoral Research]] Associate with Professor Larry Frakes at the [[University of Adelaide]].<ref name=":0" /> In 1991 she accepted a position as a lecturer in the Department of Earth Sciences at the [[University of Leeds]] UK; she was promoted to Senior Lecturer in 1996. In 2002, she was awarded the [[Polar Medal]], becoming only the fourth woman in history to receive the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reporter.leeds.ac.uk/480/honours.htm|title=Reporter 480, 22 April 2002 -|website=reporter.leeds.ac.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref>
She was promoted to Professor of Palaeoclimatology in the School of Earth and Environment and was the Director for the Centre for Polar Science at the University of Leeds,<ref name="University of Leeds Faculty of Environment"/> before becoming Dean of the Faculty of Environment in 2008.<ref name=":0"/> She is an Honorary Professor at the University of Leeds. On 1 October 2013 Professor Francis took up her post as Director of the [[British Antarctic Survey]], becoming the first woman Director of the institution.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jane Francis: Highlights|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#highlights|website=British Antarctic Survey|accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref>
Francis's principal interests are in [[Paleoclimatology|palaeoclimatology]] and [[Paleobotany|palaeobotany]]. She specialises in the study of fossil plants, and their use as tools for climate interpretation and information about past biodiversity:<ref name="geolsoc2001">{{cite web|url=https://www.geolsoc.org.uk/About/History/Awards-Citations-Replies-2001-Onwards/2014-Awards-Citations-replies|title=The Geological Society of London – 2014 Awards: Citations and Replies|website=www.geolsoc.org.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/project/impact-of-global-disturbances-on-evolution-of-polar-life/#about|title=Impact of global disturbances on evolution of polar life – Project – British Antarctic Survey|website=www.bas.ac.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> for example, understanding past climate change during greenhouse and icehouse periods.<ref name="bas.ac.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/|title=Jane Francis – British Antarctic Survey|website=www.bas.ac.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> Her research has emphasised the "Antarctic paradox," that although the Antarctic is largely inhospitable now, its abundant plant fossils indicate a drastically warmer past climate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Francis|first=Jane|date=2008|title=100 Million Years of Antarctic Climate Evolution: Evidence from Fossil Plants|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2007/1047/kp/kp03/of2007-1047kp03.pdf|journal=Proceedings of the 10th International Symposium on Antarctic Earth Sciences|doi=|pmid=|access-date=6 June 2016|display-authors=etal}}</ref> She has undertaken more than 16 expeditions to the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]].<ref name="sciencecouncil1">{{cite web|url=http://sciencecouncil.org/about-us/10-types-of-scientist/2014-list-of-leading-uk-practising-scientists/|title=2014 list of leading UK practising scientists – The Science Council|website=The Science Council|language=en-GB|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Francis was described by the [[Geological Society of London]] during the awarding of her Coke Medal as playing a "pivotal role in shaping and directing the Earth science carried out in polar regions, through her extensive service on a staggeringly wide range of national and international policy committees."<ref name="geolsoc2001"/> She is also the first woman to chair the Operations Working Group of Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meetings, the international forum of nations concerned with legal and operational issues in Antarctica.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ats.aq/e/ats_meetings_atcm.htm|title=ATS – The Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting (ATCM)|website=www.ats.aq|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Francis holds a number of memberships of national and international scientific bodies.<ref name="bas.ac.uk"/> She is a member of the UK [[Natural Environment Research Council]] (NERC) Executive Board; member of the Scientific Advisory Group of the [[Swedish Polar Research Secretariat]]; Executive committee member of the European Polar Board; and UK Delegate to the international [[Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research]].<ref>{{cite web|title=NERC - Membership|url=http://www.nerc.ac.uk/about/organisation/boards/executive/membership/|website=NERC|publisher=National Environmental Research Council|accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jane Francis: Highlights|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#highlights|website=British Antarctic Survey|accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref>
==Awards== Francis's contributions have been recognised with numerous awards. Most notably, she was awarded the [[Polar Medal]] in 2002 for outstanding contribution to British polar research, presented by [[Elizabeth II|H.M. Elizabeth II]], and was the fourth woman ever to receive the award.<ref name="The Reporter, University of Leeds">{{cite web|url=http://reporter.leeds.ac.uk/480/honours.htm|title=The Reporter, Issue 480|publisher=University of Leeds|date=22 April 2002|accessdate=26 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927000425/http://reporter.leeds.ac.uk/480/honours.htm|archivedate=27 September 2011}}</ref>
She received an Honorary Doctorate of Science from the University of Leeds in 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.see.leeds.ac.uk/news/news-inner/professor-jane-francis-receives-a-university-of-leeds-honorary-degree/|title=News Inner: Earth and Environment|website=www.see.leeds.ac.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> as well as an Honorary Doctorate of Environmental Science from the [[University Of Plymouth]], also in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.plymouth.ac.uk/news/legends-of-music-and-dance-take-to-the-graduation-stage-at-plymouth-university|title=Legends of music and dance take to the Graduation stage at Plymouth University|website=Plymouth University|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> In that same year she was named "Explorer Scientist" among 100 leading UK scientists by The Science Council.<ref name="sciencecouncil1"/> She also has been awarded the Coke Medal from the [[Geological Society of London]] (2014);<ref name="The Geological Society">{{cite web|url=http://www.geolsoc.org.uk/About/Awards-Grants-and-Bursaries/Society-Awards/Coke-Medals|title=The Coke Awards|date=2014|publisher=The Geological Society|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> the President's Award of the [[Paleontological Society]];<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#highlights|title=Jane Francis – British Antarctic Survey|website=www.bas.ac.uk|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> the [[Antarctica Service Medal|Antarctic Service Medal]] from the US [[National Science Foundation]];<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and the Workplace Achievement Award from the [[BBC]]'s 'eve' magazine, sponsored by [[Nivea]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In the [[2017 New Year Honours]], Francis was appointed [[Dame Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] (DCMG) for services to polar science and diplomacy.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61803|supp=y|page=N3|date=31 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/2673441 |title=Jane Francis |website=Thegazette.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-12-31}}</ref>
In 2017, Francis became the seventh Chancellor of the [[University of Leeds]], succeeding [[Melvyn Bragg]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.leeds.ac.uk/forstaff/news/article/5920/Welcome_back,_Professor_Dame_Jane_Francis|title=Welcome back, Professor Dame Jane Francis|last=Abel|first=Antoinette|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.bas.ac.uk/profile/janefr/#about British Antarctic Survey "people" page]
{{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{s-bef|before=[[Melvyn Bragg]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[University of Leeds|Chancellor of the University of Leeds]]|years=2017–}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}}

revision.comment: quick fixes: itals, rm links per [[WP:OVERLINK]], consistent use of ''khôra''
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{more footnotes|date=September 2009}} '''''Khôra''''' (also '''''chora'''''; {{lang-grc|χώρα}}) was the territory of the [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] ''[[polis]]'' outside the city proper. The term has been used in [[philosophy]] by [[Plato]] to designate a receptacle (as a “third kind” [''triton genos'']; ''[[Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]]'' 48e4), a space, a material substratum, or an interval. In Plato's account, ''khôra'' is neither being nor nonbeing but an interval between in which the "[[Theory of Forms|forms]]" were originally held; it "gives space" and has maternal overtones (a womb, matrix). [[Jacques Derrida]] has written a short text with the title ''Khôra'',Derrida J., ''Khôra'', Paris: Galilée 1993. using his [[deconstruction]]ist approach to investigate Plato's word usage. It is the origin for the recent interest in this rather obscure Greek term.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} ==Overview== Key authors addressing ''khôra'' include [[Martin Heidegger]], who refers to a "clearing" in which being happens or takes place. [[Julia Kristeva]] deploys the term as part of her analysis of the difference between the semiotic and symbolic realms, in that Plato's concept of "''khora''" is said to anticipate the emancipatory employment of semiotic activity as a way of evading the allegedly phallocentric character of symbolic activity (signification through language), which, following [[Jacques Lacan]], is regarded as an inherently limiting and oppressive form of ''[[Praxis (process)|praxis]]''. Julia Kristeva articulates the ''khôra'' in terms of a presignifying state: "Although the ''khôra'' can be designated and regulated, it can never be definively posited: as a result, one can situate the ''khôra'' and, if necessary, lend it a topology, but one can never give it axiomatic form."Kristeva, J. 1984 ''Revolution in Poetic Language''. New York, Columbia University Press. p. 26. Jacques Derrida uses ''khôra'' to name a radical otherness that "gives place" for being. [[Nader El-Bizri]] builds on this by more narrowly taking ''khôra'' to name the radical happening of an ontological difference between being and beings.([[Nader El-Bizri]], 2004, 2011) El-Bizri's reflections on "''khôra''" are taken as a basis for tackling the meditations on ''dwelling'' and on ''being and space'' in [[Heidegger]]'s thought and the critical conceptions of space and place as they evolved in [[architectural theory]] and in history of philosophy and science, with a focus on geometry and optics.([[Nader El-Bizri]], 2001, 2004, 2011, 2015) Derrida argues that the [[subjectile]] is like Plato’s ''khôra'', Greek for space, receptacle or site. Plato proposes that the ''khôra'' rests between the sensible and the intelligible, through which everything passes but in which nothing is retained. For example, an image needs to be held by something, just as a mirror will hold a reflection. For Derrida, ''khôra'' defies attempts at naming or either/or logic, which he "deconstructs". See also Derrida's collaborative project with architect [[Peter Eisenmann]], in ''Chora L Works: Jacques Derrida and Peter Eisenman''.[https://www.amazon.com/Chora-Works-Jacques-Derrida-Eisenman/dp/1885254407 ''Chora L Works: Jacques Derrida and Peter Eisenman''] The project proposed the construction of a garden in the [[Parc de la Villette]] in Paris, which included a sieve, or harp-like structure that Derrida envisaged as a physical metaphor for the receptacle-like properties of the ''khôra''. The concept of the ''khôra'', distinguished by its elusive properties, would have become a physical reality had the project been realised. Following Derrida, [[John Caputo]] describes ''khôra'' as:
neither present nor absent, active or passive, the good nor evil, living nor nonliving - but rather atheological and nonhuman - ''khôra'' is not even a receptacle. ''Khôra'' has no meaning or essence, no identity to fall back upon. She/it receives all without becoming anything, which is why she/it can become the subject of neither a philosopheme nor mytheme. In short, the ''khôra'' is tout autre [fully other], very.{{Harvnb|Caputo|1997|pp=35–36}}
If, as one contributor concludes, "''khôra''" means "space", it is an interesting space that "at times appears to be neither this nor that, at times both this and that," wavering "between the logic of exclusion and that of participation." (Derrida, ''The Name'', 89). ==See also== *[[Phenomenology (architecture)]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite journal|last=[[Jacques Derrida|Derrida]] |first=Jacques |year=1995 |contribution=Khôra |editor=T. Dutoit |title=On the Name |location=Stanford |publisher=Stanford University Press}} Translation of Derrida, Jacques 1993: ''Khôra''. Paris: Galilée. *{{cite journal|last=[[John D. Caputo|Caputo]] |first=John D. |year=2004 |title=Love among the Deconsructibles: A Response to Gregg Lambert |journal=JCRT |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=37ff |url=http://www.jcrt.org/archives/05.2/caputo.pdf}} *[[Nader El-Bizri]], "‘''Qui-êtes vous Khôra?''’: Receiving [[Plato]]’s ''[[Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]]''," ''Existentia Meletai-Sophias'', Vol. XI, Issue 3-4 (2001), pp. 473–490 *[[Nader El-Bizri]], "''ON KAI KHORA'': Situating [[Heidegger]] between the ''[[Sophist]]'' and the ''[[Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]]''," ''Studia Phaenomenologica'', Vol. IV, Issue 1-2 (2004), pp. 73–98 [http://www.zetabooks.com/studia-phaenomenologica-volume-4-issue-1-2-2004-issues-on-brentano-husserl-and-heidegger.html]. *[[Nader El-Bizri]], "''Ontopoiēsis'' and the Interpretation of [[Plato]]’s ''Khôra''," ''Analecta Husserliana: The Yearbook of Phenomenological Research'', Vol. LXXXIII (2004), pp. 25–45. *[[Nader El-Bizri]], "Being at Home Among Things: [[Heidegger]]’s Reflections on Dwelling", ''Environment, Space, Place'' Vol. 3 (2011), pp. 47–71 *[[Nader El-Bizri]], "On Dwelling: Heideggerian Allusions to Architectural [[Phenomenology (architecture)|Phenomenology]]", ''Studia UBB. Philosophia'', Vol. 60, No. 1 (2015): 5-30 *Fernández Agis, Domingo, "Cuerpo, Khôra y espacio político" [http://www.revistadefilosofia.com/14-02.pdf] ==External links== * {{wiktionary-inline|χώρα}} __NOTOC__ {{DEFAULTSORT:Khora}} [[Category:Concepts in ancient Greek metaphysics]] [[Category:Natural philosophy]] [[Category:Platonism]]

revision.text:
{{Main article|Stratovolcano}} A '''list of stratovolcanoes''' active in [[Holocene|geologically recent (Holocene) times]] follows below. The [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Global Volcanism Program]] database lists more than 700 such [[stratovolcano]]es. {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
==[[Africa]]== [[File:Pt Thomson Batian Nelion Mt Kenya.JPG|thumb|right|[[Mount Kenya]] in 1972.]] [[File:LavaDusk.jpg|thumb|right|Lava lake inside [[Mount Nyiragongo]].]]
=== [[Cameroon]] === * [[Mount Cameroon]]
=== [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] === * [[Mount Nyiragongo]], [[Goma]]. Listed as a [[Decade Volcano]]. It contains an active [[lava lake]] inside its crater which overflowed due to cracks in 2002.
=== [[Eritrea]] === * [[Alid Volcano]]
=== [[Ethiopia]] === * [[Borawli]], [[Afar Region]], [[Ethiopia]]
=== [[Kenya]] === * [[Mount Kenya]], which contains several volcanic plugs on its peak.
=== [[Tanzania]] === * [[Ol Doinyo Lengai]], the Earth's only active [[carbonatite]] lava-producing volcano. * [[Mount Kilimanjaro]], a dormant stratovolcano. It is the highest point of Africa. * [[Mount Meru (Tanzania)|Mount Meru]]
===[[Mid-Atlantic Ridge]]=== * [[Mount Pico]] in [[Pico Island]], [[Azores]], [[Portugal]] * [[Teide]] in [[Tenerife]], [[Canary Islands]], [[Spain]] * [[Cumbre Vieja]] in [[La Palma]], [[Canary Islands]], [[Spain]] * [[Mount Fogo]] in [[Fogo, Cape Verde|Fogo]], [[Cape Verde]] * [[Green Mountain]], [[Ascension Island]]
==[[Americas]]==
===[[Caribbean]]=== * [[La Grande Soufrière]] on the island of [[Basse-Terre]] in [[Guadaloupe]], [[West Indies]]<ref>[http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/tag/stratovolcano/page/14/ Soufrière Guadaloupe, West Indies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710212209/http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/tag/stratovolcano/page/14/ |date=2011-07-10 }}</ref> * The [[Soufriere Hills]] on the island of [[Montserrat]]. Its 1995 eruptions resulted in the abandonment of its capital city, [[Plymouth, Montserrat|Plymouth]]. * [[Soufrière (volcano)]] in [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] * [[Mount Pelée]] in [[Martinique]]. Its devastating eruption in 08 May 1902, resulted in the complete destruction of its capital city, [[Saint-Pierre, Martinique|Saint-Pierre]], with the deaths of more than 30,000 inhabitants within it. * [[Mount Scenery]] in the [[Caribbean Netherlands]]
===[[Central America]]=== [[File:arenallong.jpg|thumb|right|[[Arenal Volcano]] in November 2006.]]
====[[Costa Rica]]==== * [[Arenal Volcano|Arenal]], [[Chato Volcano|Chato]] and [[Poás Volcano|Poás]] in [[Alajuela Province|Alajuela]] * [[Irazu Volcano|Irazu]] and [[Turrialba Volcano|Turrialba]] in [[Cartago Province|Cartago]]
====[[El Salvador]]====
* [[San Miguel (volcano)|San Miguel]] and [[Chinameca (volcano)|Chinameca]] in [[San Miguel Department (El Salvador)|San Miguel department]] * [[Santa Ana Volcano|Santa Ana]] in [[Santa Ana department]] * [[Chichontepec]] * [[Guazapa (volcano)|Guazapa]] * [[Taburete]] * [[Izalco (volcano)|Izalco]]
====[[Panamá]]==== * [[Volcán Barú]]
[[File:Guatemalacityvolcanoes.jpg|thumbnail|(From left to right) [[Volcán de Agua|Agua]], [[Volcán de Fuego|Fuego]], and [[Acatenango]] volcanoes, taken from [[Guatemala City]].]]
====[[Guatemala]]==== * [[Volcán Tacaná]] on the border between [[Mexico]] and [[Guatemala]] * [[Volcán Tajumulco]] Highest point and highest volcano in [[Central America]] * [[Almolonga|Volcán Cerro Quemado (Almolonga)]] * [[Santa María (volcano)|Volcán Santa María]], a [[Decade Volcano]]. It has a smaller peak called [[Santiaguito]]. * [[Siete Orejas Volcano|Volcán Siete Orejas]] * [[San Pedro (volcano)|Volcán San Pedro]] * [[Volcán Atitlán]] * [[Volcán Tolimán]] * [[Acatenango]] * [[Volcán de Fuego]]. It recently erupted in June 2018. * [[Volcán de Agua]] * [[Pacaya]] * [[Tecuamburro]] * [[Tahual]] * [[Jumay Volcano|Volcán Jumay]] * [[Volcán Ipala]] * [[Suchitan|Suchitán]] * [[Moyuta (volcano)|Volcán Moyuta]] * [[Chingo|Volcán Chingo]] on the border between [[Guatemala]] and [[El Salvador]]
===[[North America]]===
[[Image:Mount Rainier over Tacoma.jpg|thumb|right| Northwest side of [[Mount Rainier]] seen from [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]]]] [[File:Pyroclastic and Cayley.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Mount Cayley]] volcanic complex on August 13, 2005. Summits left to right are Pyroclastic Peak and Mount Cayley.]] [[File:Mount Adams 3503s.JPG|thumb|right|[[Mount Adams (Washington)|Mount Adams]], 2013]] [[File:Mount_Hood_2619s.jpg|thumb|right|[[Mount Hood]], 2017]]
====[[Canada]]==== =====[[Northwest Territories]]===== * [[Back River volcanic complex]] =====Northern [[British Columbia]]===== * [[Hoodoo Mountain]] * [[Mount Edziza]] =====Southern [[British Columbia]]===== * [[Mount Boucherie]] * [[Mount Cayley massif]] See also [[Mount Cayley volcanic field]]. * [[Mount Garibaldi]] * [[Mount Meager massif]] About 2,400 years ago, it produced the most recent major catastrophic eruption in Canada. * [[Mount Price (British Columbia)|Mount Price]] * [[The Black Tusk]] * [[Coquihalla Mountain]]
====[[Mexico]]==== * [[Popocatépetl]], just 70 km (43 mi) southeast of [[Mexico City]] * [[Colima (volcano)|Colima]], designated as a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Nevado de Toluca]] * [[Pico de Orizaba]]
====[[United States]]==== =====[[Alaska]]===== * [[Mount Akutan]] * [[Augustine Volcano]], [[Cook Inlet]] * [[Mount Bona]] * [[Mount Churchill]] * [[Cleveland (volcano)|Cleveland volcano]] * [[Frosty Peak Volcano]] * [[Mount Katmai]], [[Katmai National Park and Preserve]] * [[Korovin Volcano]] * [[Mount Mageik]] * [[Mount Pavlof]] * [[Mount Redoubt (Alaska)|Mount Redoubt]] * [[Mount Shishaldin]] * [[Mount Vsevidof]] =====[[Washington (state)|Washington]]===== * [[Mount Baker]] * [[Glacier Peak]] * [[Mount Rainier]] * [[Mount St. Helens]]. In May 18, 1980, it produced a large eruption preceded by a massive landslide which decimated the volcano's height. * [[Mount Adams (Washington)|Mount Adams]] =====[[Oregon]]===== * [[Mount Hood]] * [[Mount Jefferson (Oregon)|Mount Jefferson]] * [[Black Butte (Oregon)|Black Butte]] * [[Three Sisters (Oregon)|The Three Sisters]] * [[Broken Top]] * [[Mount Bachelor]] *[[Mount Scott (Klamath County, Oregon)]] *[[Mount McLoughlin]]
=====[[California]]===== * [[Mount Shasta]]
=====[[Arizona]]===== * [[San Francisco Mountain]] =====[[New Mexico]]===== * [[Mount Taylor (New Mexico)|Mount Taylor]]
===[[South America]]=== [[File:San vicente els.jpg|thumb|right|[[San Vicente (volcano)|San Vicente]] in 1994]] [[File:Acotango.jpg|thumb|right|A view of [[Acotango]] from [[Chungará Lake]]]] [[File:Lanin1997.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lanín]], January 1997]]
====Chile==== * [[Llaima]] * [[Irruputuncu]] on the border of [[Bolivia]] and [[Chile]] * [[Ojos del Salado]], the highest volcano in the [[world]]. It is on the border between [[Argentina]] and [[Chile]]. * [[Villarrica (volcano)|Villarrica]] * [[Cerro Arenales]] * [[Calbuco (volcano)|Calbuco]]. It recently erupted in April 2015. * [[Callaqui]] * [[Mount Hudson]] * [[Copahue]] * [[Lascar Volcano]] * [[Nevados de Chillán]] * [[Lanín]] on the border between [[Argentina]] and [[Chile]] * [[Acotango]] on the border between [[Bolivia]] and [[Chile]] * [[Cerro Solo]] in [[Patagonia]] along the border between [[Chile]] and [[Argentina]] * [[Parinacota Volcano|Parinacota]]. Erupted April 2008 * [[Licancabur]] * [[Sierra Nevada (stratovolcano)|Sierra Nevada]] * [[Chaitén (volcano)|Chaitén]]
====[[Colombia]]==== * [[Galeras]], a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Nevado del Ruiz]] in the Department of [[Tolima Department|Tolima]]. A 1985 eruption created destructive [[lahar]] floods which engulfed the nearby town of Armero.
====[[Ecuador]]==== * [[Pichincha Volcano]] * [[Tungurahua]] * [[Sangay]] * [[Reventador]] * [[Chimborazo (volcano)|Chimborazo]] * [[Cotopaxi]] * [[Antisana]] * [[Cayambe (volcano)|Cayambe]] * [[Corazón (volcano)|Corazón]] * [[El Altar]] * [[Carihuairazo]]
====[[Peru]]==== * [[Coropuna]] * [[Huaynaputina]] * [[El Misti]] near the southern city of [[Arequipa]] * [[Sabancaya]] * [[Ubinas]] southwestern [[Peru]] * [[Tutupaca]] * [[Yucamane]]
==[[Antarctica]]== * [[Mount Erebus]] * [[Penguin Island (South Shetland Islands)|Penguin Island]] *[[Mount Bird]] *[[Brown Peak (Sturge Island)|Brown Peak]] *[[Mount Discovery]] *[[Mount Harcourt]] *[[Mount Melbourne]] *[[Mount Morning]] *[[Mount Overlord]]
==[[Asia]]==
===[[Western Asia]]===
==== [[Iran]] ==== * [[Bazman]] * [[Sahand]] * [[Sabalan]] * [[Mount Damavand]], in [[Amol County]] of [[Māzandarān]] * [[Taftan Volcano]] in [[Sistan and Baluchestan Province]]
==== [[Turkey]] ==== [[File:NEO ararat big.jpg|thumb|Satellite picture of Mount Ararat]]
* [[Mount Hasan]] * [[Mount Ararat]] and [[Little Ararat]] * [[Mount Erciyes]]
==== [[Yemen]] ==== * [[Jabal al-Tair Island|Jabal al-Tair]], an island volcano within the [[Red Sea]] off the coast of [[Yemen]]
===[[South Asia]]===
==== [[India]] ==== * [[Barren Island (Andaman Islands)|Barren Island]], the only active stratovolcano in the [[Indian subcontinent]]
===[[Southeast Asia]]===
==== [[Indonesia]] ==== [[File:Indonesia, Sunda Straits.jpg|thumb|[[Volcanic]] activity at [[Anak Krakatau]]]]
* [[Mount Kerinci]] and [[Mount Sinabung]] in [[Sumatra]] * [[Mount Rinjani]] in [[Lombok]] * [[Mount Semeru]] and [[Mount Bromo]] in [[East Java]]. Together, they form the [[Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park]]. * [[Mount Agung]] and [[Mount Batur]] in [[Bali]] * [[Galunggung]] in [[West Java]]. * [[Krakatoa]]. A violent eruption in August 1883 resulted in the obliteration of the three-peaked volcanic island. ** [[Anak Krakatoa]]. It emerged from the sea in 1927-1930 * [[Mount Merapi]] in [[Central Java]]. It is listed as a [[Decade Volcano]]. * [[Mount Tambora]] in the island of [[Sumbawa]]. Its catastrophic eruption in 1815 caused a [[Year Without a Summer]] in 1816. * [[Mount Kelud]] in [[East Java]]
[[File:Pinatubo91eruption clark air base.jpg|thumb|Ash plume of [[Mount Pinatubo]] during the June 1991 eruption]]
==== [[Malaysia]] ==== * [[Bombalai Hill]] in [[Sabah]], [[Borneo]]
==== [[Philippines]] ==== [[File:BICOL MAY 3-8, 2010 256.jpg|thumb|[[Mayon Volcano]] in May 08, 2010]]
* [[Mayon Volcano]] in [[Albay]], The most active volcano in the Philippines, famous for its perfect symmetrical cone shape. * [[Mount Pinatubo]] in [[Zambales]]. The catastrophic June 1991 eruption, which formed a caldera, later filled by a [[crater lake]], had global environmental effects. * [[Mount Bulusan]] in [[Sorsogon]] * [[Mount Kanlaon]] and [[Mount Talinis]] in [[Negros (Philippines)|Negros]] * [[Mount Arayat]] in [[Pampanga]] * [[Mount Iriga]] and [[Mount Isarog]] in [[Camarines Sur]] * [[Mount Mariveles]] and [[Mount Natib]] in [[Bataan]] * [[Mount Malindig]] in [[Marinduque]] * [[Mount Apo]] in [[Davao City]], [[Mindanao]]. Considered a dormant volcano, it is the highest point of the Philippines * [[Mount Makiling]] in [[Laguna (province)|Laguna]] * [[Mount Banahaw]] in [[Quezon]] is one of the active volcanoes in the Philippines. Its 1730 eruption caused a debris avalanche and crater lake collapse which flooded [[Sariaya]], Quezon.
===[[East Asia]]===
==== [[North Korea]] ==== * [[Baekdu Mountain]], on the border between [[North Korea]] and [[China]]
==== [[Japan]] ==== [[File:Mt,Fuji 2007 Winter 28000Ft.JPG|thumb|Peak of [[Mt. Fuji]]]]
* [[Mount Fuji]]. Highest point of the country. Last erupted in 1708 * [[Mount Mihara]] on [[Izu Oshima]] * [[Sakurajima]], designated as a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Mount Unzen]]. Erupted in 1991. Listed as a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Mount Adatara]] * [[Mount Haruna]] * [[Mount Yufu]]
==== [[Taiwan]] ==== * [[Guishan Island (Yilan)|Guishan Island]]
=== [[Northern Asia]] ===
==== [[Russia]] ==== [[File:Klyuchevskoi.jpg|thumb|Klyuchevskaya Sopka in July 2006]]
* [[Bezymianny]]<ref>[http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/europe/russia/bezymianny-russia/ Bezymianny volcano, Russia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507161606/http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/europe/russia/bezymianny-russia/ |date=2011-05-07 }}</ref> * [[Klyuchevskaya Sopka]] or Kliuchevskoi, [[Kamchatka Krai]], the highest active volcano in Eurasia * [[Shiveluch]], [[Kamchatka Krai]] * [[Avachinsky]], [[Kamchatka Krai]], a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Koryaksky]],<ref>[http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/europe/russia/koryaksky-russia/ Koryaksky Volcano, Russia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316174142/http://explorevolcanoesnow.com/europe/russia/koryaksky-russia/ |date=2012-03-16 }}</ref> [[Kamchatka Krai]], also a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Karymsky (volcano)|Karymsky]], [[Kamchatka Krai]] * [[Mount Elbrus]] in the [[Caucasus Mountains|Caucasus]]. It is the highest point in the [[Europe|European continent]].
==[[Europe]]== [[File:Snaefellsnes-Snaefellsjökull-Summit-20030529.jpg|thumb|right|The summit of [[Snæfellsjökull]].]] [[Image:Etna eruption seen from the International Space Station.jpg|thumb|right|Etna's 2002 eruption, photographed from the [[International Space Station|ISS]].]] [[File:Vesuvius from plane.jpg|thumb|right|Aerial view of Mount Vesuvius.]]
===[[Western Europe]]===
==== [[France]] ==== * [[Puy de Sancy]], in [[Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes]]
==== [[Italy]] ==== * [[Mount Etna]] near [[Catania]] in [[Sicily]]. Tallest active volcano in Europe. Recently erupted in 2013 and volcanic activity is still ongoing. Listed as a [[Decade Volcano]]. * [[Mount Vesuvius]], located 09 kilometers (05.6 miles) east of [[Naples]] in [[Campania]]. Famous for its violent eruption in [[Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD 79|August 24, A.D. 79]]. Its last eruption happened in March 1944. A [[Decade Volcano]]. * [[Stromboli]] and [[Vulcano]], two of the [[Lipari Islands]]. The former has been continuously erupting for more than two millennia, making it the second most active volcano in Europe.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}}. The latter last erupted in 1890. * [[Alban Hills]], located 20 kilometers (12 miles) east of [[Rome]] in [[Lazio]]. Last eruption happened in about 5,000 BC.
===[[Caucasus]]===
==== [[Armenia]] ==== * [[Aragats]]
==== [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] ==== * [[Didi Abuli]]
* [[Kazbek|Mount Kazbek]] * [[Samsari|Mount Samsari]] * [[Tavkvetili|Mount Tavkvetili]] * [[Tsiteli Khati]]
===[[Scandinavia]]===
==== [[Iceland]] ==== * [[Askja]] * [[Bárðarbunga]]. Recently erupted between [[2014–2015 eruption of Bárðarbunga|2014 to 2015]] * [[Eldfell]] and [[Helgafell (volcano)|Helgafell]] in the island of [[Heimaey]] * [[Eyjafjallajökull]]. Erupted in 2010, which caused a major air traffic halts and flight cancellations in Europe and neighboring areas. * [[Hekla]] * [[Kverkfjöll]] * [[Snæfellsjökull]] * [[Öræfajökull]] * [[Kollóttadyngja]]
==== [[Norway]] ==== * [[Beerenberg]] in [[Jan Mayen]], the world's northernmost active volcano
==[[Oceania]]==
=== [[Northern Mariana Islands]] === * [[Anatahan]] in [[Northern Mariana Islands]]
=== [[New Zealand]] === * [[Mount Taranaki|Mount Taranaki/Egmont]] in [[Egmont National Park]] in [[North Island]] * [[Mount Ngauruhoe]] in North Island * [[Mount Ruapehu]] in [[Tongariro National Park]] * [[Whakaari / White Island|Whakaari/White Island]] in [[Bay of Plenty]] * [[Banks Peninsula]] in [[Christchurch]], [[South Island]]
=== Papua New Guinea === * [[Tavurvur]]. Recently erupted in 2014. * [[Ulawun]], a [[Decade Volcano]] * [[Kadovar]], which erupted for the first recorded time in 2018
